title: What happens after I file a VA disability claim?. disability after you file claim
content: Claim received We’ll let you know when we receive your VA disability claim. If you file your claim online,you’ll get an on-screen message from us after you submit the form. If you file your claim online, If you mail your application,we’ll send you a letter to let you know we have your claim. You should get this letter about 1 week, plus mailing time, after we receive your claim. If you mail your application, Initial review We’ll review your claim. Evidence gathering, review, and decision During this step, we’ll do 3 things: Ask for evidence from you, health care providers, government agencies, or others Review the evidence Make a decision If we need more evidence during the review, your claim may return to this step more than once. title: About VA DIC for spouses, dependents, and parents. disability dependency indemnity compensation
content: If you’re the surviving spouse, child, or parent of a service member who died in the line of duty, or the survivor of a Veteran who died from a service-related injury or illness, you may be able to get a tax-free monetary benefit called VA Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (VA DIC). Find out if you can get VA benefits or compensation.

title: Am I eligible for VA DIC as a surviving spouse or dependent?. disability dependency indemnity compensation
content: As a surviving spouse Eligibility You may be eligible for VA benefits or compensation if you meet these requirements. One of these must be true: One of these must be true: You lived with the Veteran or service member without a break until their death,or or If you’re separated, you weren’t at fault for the separation And one of these must be true: And one of these must be true: You married the Veteran or service member within 15 years of their discharge from the period of military service during which the qualifying illness or injury started or got worse,or or You were married to the Veteran or service member for at least 1 year,or or You had a child with the Veteran or service member Note:If you remarried, you can receive or continue to receive compensation if one of these describes you: Note: You remarried on or after December 16, 2003, and you were 57 years of age or older at the time you remarried,or or You remarried on or after January 5, 2021, and you were 55 years of age or older at the time you remarried Evidence You’ll need to provide evidence with your claim showing that one of these descriptions is true for the Veteran or service member. Evidence may include documents like military service records, doctor’s reports, and medical test results. Provide evidence showing that one of these is true: Provide evidence showing that one of these is true: The service member died while on active duty, active duty for training, or inactive-duty training,or or The Veteran died from a service-connected illness or injury,or or The Veteran didn’t die from a service-connected illness or injury, but was eligible to receive VA compensation for a service-connected disability rated as totally disabling for a certain period of time If the Veteran’s eligibility was due to a rating of totally disabling, they must have had this rating: If the Veteran’s eligibility was due to a rating of totally disabling, they must have had this rating: For at least 10 years before their death,or or Since their release from active duty and for at least 5 years immediately before their death,or or For at least 1 year before their death if they were a former prisoner of war who died after September 30, 1999 Note:“Totally disabling” means the Veteran’s injuries made it impossible for them to work. Note: Learn more about the evidence you’ll need to support your claim As a surviving child Eligibility You may be eligible for VA benefits or compensation if you meet these requirements. All of these must be true: All of these must be true: You aren’t married,and and You aren’t included on the surviving spouse’s compensation,and and You’re under the age of 18 (or under the age of 23 if attending school) Note:If you were adopted out of the Veteran’s or service member’s family, but meet all other eligibility criteria, you still qualify for compensation. Note: Evidence You’ll need to provide evidence with your claim showing that one of these descriptions is true for the Veteran or service member. Evidence may include documents like military service records, doctor’s reports, and medical test results. Provide evidence showing that one of these is true: Provide evidence showing that one of these is true: The service member died while on active duty, active duty for training, or inactive-duty training,or or The Veteran died from a service-connected illness or injury,or or The Veteran didn’t die from a service-connected illness or injury, but was eligible to receive VA compensation for a service-connected disability that was rated as totally disabling for a certain period of time If the Veteran’s eligibility was due to a service-connected disability rated as totally disabling, they must have had this rating: If the Veteran’s eligibility was due to a service-connected disability rated as totally disabling, they must have had this rating: For at least 10 years before their death,or or Since their release from active duty and for at least 5 years immediately before their death,or or For at least 1 year before their death if they were a former prisoner of war who died after September 30, 1999 Note:“Totally disabling” means the Veteran’s injuries make it impossible for them to work. Note: Learn more about the evidence you’ll need to support your claim As a surviving parent Eligibility You may be eligible for VA benefits or compensation if you meet these requirements. Both of these must be true: Both of these must be true: You’re the biological, adoptive, or foster parent of the Veteran or service member,and and Your income is below a certain amountCheck the parents DIC rate table Note:We define a foster parent as someone who served in the role of a parent to the Veteran or service member before their last entry into active service. Note: Evidence You’ll need to provide evidence with your claim showing that one of these descriptions is true for the Veteran or service member. Evidence may include documents like military service records, doctor’s reports, and medical test results. Provide evidence showing that one of these is true: Provide evidence showing that one of these is true: The service member died from an injury or illness while on active duty or in the line of duty while on active duty for training,or The service member died from an injury or illness while on active duty or in the line of duty while on active duty for training,or or The service member died from an injury or certain illnesses in the line of duty while on inactive training,or The service member died from an injury or certain illnesses in the line of duty while on inactive training,or or The Veteran died from a service-connected illness or injury The Veteran died from a service-connected illness or injury Learn more about the evidence you’ll need to support your claim Note:If you’re the survivor of a Veteran who died from COVID-19 and a service-related condition made their illness worse, you may be eligible for VA DIC. When we review your application, we’ll consider whether a service-related condition contributed to your loved one’s illness. Note:

title: What kind of benefits can I get?. disability dependency indemnity compensation
content: If you qualify, you can get tax-free monetary benefits. The amount you receive depends on the type of survivor you are. DIC benefit rates for surviving spouses and children DIC benefits for surviving parents

title: How do I apply for compensation?. disability dependency indemnity compensation
content: First you’ll need to fill out an application for benefits. The application you fill out will depend on your survivor status. If you’re the surviving spouse or child of a service member who died while on active duty,your military casualty assistance officer will help you to complete an Application for DIC, Death Pension, and/or Accrued Benefits by a Surviving Spouse or Child (VA Form 21P-534a). The officer will help you mail the form to the correct VA regional office. If you’re the surviving spouse or child of a service member who died while on active duty, Get VA Form 21P-534a to download If you’re the surviving spouse or child of a Veteran,fill out an Application for DIC, Death Pension, and/or Accrued Benefits (VA Form 21P-534EZ). If you’re the surviving spouse or child of a Veteran, Get VA Form 21P-534EZ to download If you’re a surviving parent,fill out an Application for Dependency and Indemnity Compensation by Parent(s) (VA Form 21P-535). If you’re a surviving parent, Get VA Form 21P-535 to download You can apply for this benefit in any of these ways: Work with an accredited attorney, claims agent, or Veterans Service Organization (VSO) representative.Get help filing a claim Use the QuickSubmit tool through AccessVA to upload your form online.Go to AccessVA to use QuickSubmit Mail your form to this address:Department of Veterans AffairsPension Intake CenterPO Box 5365Janesville, WI 53547-5365 Mail your form to this address: Department of Veterans AffairsPension Intake CenterPO Box 5365Janesville, WI 53547-5365 Go to a VA regional office and get help from a VA employee.Find a VA regional office near you

title: Should I submit an intent to file form?. disability dependency indemnity compensation
content: You may want to submit an intent to file form before you apply for DIC benefits. This can give you the time you need to gather your evidence while avoiding a later potential start date (also called an effective date). When you notify us of your intent to file, you may be able to get retroactive payments (payments that start at a point in the past). Find out how to submit an intent to file form

title: Exposure to hazardous chemicals and materials. disability eligibility hazardous materials exposure
content: Learn about chemical hazards or other hazardous materials you may have come in contact with during military service. And find out if you can get VA disability compensation for illnesses or conditions related to these exposures. We call these presumptive conditions.

title: Agent Orange. disability eligibility hazardous materials exposure
content: Agent Orange If you served in the Republic of Vietnam or in or near the Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) during the Vietnam Era—or in certain related jobs—you may have had contact with Agent Orange, an herbicide used to clear plants and trees during the war. Learn about compensation based on Agent Orange exposure Asbestos If you worked in certain military jobs, you may have had contact with asbestos (toxic fibers once used in many buildings and products). Learn about compensation based on asbestos exposure Birth defects like spina bifida If you served in the Republic of Vietnam, in Thailand, or in or near the Korean DMZ during the Vietnam Era—and your child has spina bifida or certain other birth defects—your child may be eligible for disability benefits. Learn about compensation based on birth defects like spina bifida Burn pits and other specific environmental hazards If you served in Iraq, Afghanistan, or certain other areas, you may have had contact with toxic chemicals in the air, water, or soil. Learn about compensation based on burn pits and other specific environmental hazards Contact with mustard gas or lewisite If you served at the German bombing of Bari, Italy, in World War II or worked in certain other jobs, you may have had contact with mustard gas. Learn about compensation based on mustard gas or lewisite exposure Contaminated drinking water at Camp Lejeune If you served at Camp Lejeune or MCAS New River between August 1953 and December 1987, you may be at risk of certain illnesses believed to be caused by contaminants found in the drinking water during that time. Learn about compensation based on contaminated drinking water at Camp Lejeune Gulf War Illnesses in Southwest Asia If you served in the Southwest Asia theater of operations, you may be at risk of certain illnesses or other conditions linked to this region. Learn about compensation based on Gulf War illnesses in Southwest Asia Gulf War Illnesses in Afghanistan If you served in Afghanistan, you may be at risk of certain illnesses or other conditions linked to this region. Learn about compensation based on Gulf War illnesses in Afghanistan Project 112 or Project SHAD If you were part of warfare testing for Project 112 or Project Shipboard Hazard and Defense (SHAD) from 1962 to 1974, you may be at risk of illnesses believed to be caused by chemical testing. Learn about compensation based on Project 112/SHAD Radiation exposure If you served in the post-WWII occupation of Hiroshima or Nagasaki, were imprisoned in Japan, worked with or near nuclear weapons testing, or served at a gaseous diffusion plant or in certain other jobs, you may be at risk of illnesses believed to be caused by radiation. Learn about compensation based on radiation exposure

title: Disabilities that appear within 1 year after discharge. disability eligibility illnesses within one year of discharge
content: If you have certain chronic (long-lasting) conditions that started within 1 year after your discharge from active military service, you may be eligible for VA disability compensation. Eligible conditions include high blood pressure (hypertension), arthritis, diabetes, or peptic ulcers. Compensation provides tax-free monthly payments. Keep reading to find out if you may be eligible.

title: How do I file a claim for compensation?. disability eligibility illnesses within one year of discharge
content: You can file a claim online now. You can also file by mail, in person, or with the help of a trained professional. File for disability compensation online Learn about other ways to file a disability compensation claim

title: What evidence will I need to provide to support my claim?. disability eligibility illnesses within one year of discharge
content: Here’s what you’ll need to provide: Evidence that your condition is at least 10% disabling (like a doctor’s report that shows you take medicine for your high blood pressure),and and Evidence that your condition appeared within 1 year after your discharge from active service (like a medical report with the date of your diagnosis) Note:If you have a condition listed in Title 38, Code of Federal Regulation, 3.309(a), you won’t need to show the problem started during—or got worse because of—your military service. This is because we automatically assume (or “presume”) that certain conditions that appear within 1 year after discharge are caused by your service. We call these presumptive conditions. Note: Download Title 38, Code of Federal Regulation, 3.309(a) for a complete list of covered illnesses (DOC)

title: Are any illnesses covered if they appear more than 1 year after discharge?. disability eligibility illnesses within one year of discharge
content: Yes. You may be eligible for disability compensation for these illnesses, even if they appear more than 1 year after discharge: Hansen’s disease(a long-lasting infection that affects your skin, nerves, and mucous membranes) can appear within 3 years after discharge. Hansen’s disease Tuberculosis(an infection that attacks your lungs and sometimes other areas of your body) can appear within 3 years after discharge. Tuberculosis Multiple sclerosis(a long-lasting illness that can cause numbness, weakness, and many other symptoms) can appear within 7 years after discharge. Multiple sclerosis Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease (a long-lasting illness that affects muscle control), can appear any time after discharge. title: Disability compensation for PTSD. disability eligibility ptsd
content: If you have posttraumatic stress from a traumatic event you experienced during your service, you may be eligible for VA disability compensation for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Compensation provides tax-free monthly payments. Keep reading to find out if you may be eligible. Learn more about PTSD

title: What does VA consider to be a traumatic event?. disability eligibility ptsd
content: We consider any of these to be a traumatic event: You suffered a serious injury, personal or sexual trauma, or sexual violation,or or Someone or something threatened you with injury, sexual assault, or death

title: Eligibility for VA disability benefits. disability eligibility
content: VA disability compensation provides tax-free monthly payments. If you have a service-connected condition, you may be eligible for compensation. title: Fully Developed Claims program. disability how to file claim evidence needed fully developed claims
content: If you want to get a faster decision on your disability benefits claim by submitting evidence along with your claim, use the Fully Developed Claims program. Find out how to submit a fully developed claim. And learn what evidence you’ll need to submit along with your claim.

title: What do I need to do to submit a fully developed claim?. disability how to file claim evidence needed fully developed claims
content: Here’s what you’ll need to do for us to consider your claim fully developed: Here’s what you’ll need to do for us to consider your claim fully developed: Submit your completedApplication for Disability Compensation and Related Compensation Benefits (VA Form 21-526EZ),and and Submit all the evidence (supporting documents) you have along with your claim,and and Certify that there’s no more evidence we might need to decide your claim,and and Go to any VA medical exams that we schedule, if we decide these exams are needed to make a decision on your claim

title: What evidence will I need to submit along with my disability claim?. disability how to file claim evidence needed fully developed claims
content: You’ll need to submit this evidence: You’ll need to submit this evidence: All private medical records related to the claimed condition, like reports from your own doctor or X-rays or other test results from a non-VA hospital or other treatment center,and and Any records of medical treatment you’ve received for the claimed condition while serving in the military,and and Any military personnel records you have that relate to the claimed condition,and and Information about any related health records that you don’t have but that we can request on your behalf from a federal facility like a VA medical center or clinic If you think your service records don’t include a description of your disability, you can also submit letters from family members, friends, clergy members, law enforcement personnel, or those you served with that can tell us more about your claimed condition and how and when it happened. If you think your service records don’t include a description of your disability Note:In 1973, a fire at the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) in St. Louis destroyed records held for Veterans who were discharged from the Army and Air Force during certain periods of time. If your records were destroyed in this fire, you can get help reconstructing them. Note: Find out how to reconstruct your records

title: Are there any risks to using the Fully Developed Claims program?. disability how to file claim evidence needed fully developed claims
content: No. Filing a fully developed claim won’t affect the attention we give to your claim or the benefits you’re entitled to receive. If we determine that we need other non-federal records to make a decision on your claim, we’ll simply remove the claim from the Fully Developed Claims program and process it as a standard claim.

title: What should the evidence show to support my disability claim?. disability how to file claim evidence needed fully developed claims
content: This depends on the type of claim you’re filing. Check what evidence is needed for different types of claims

title: Can VA help me gather evidence?. disability how to file claim evidence needed fully developed claims
content: Yes. We can help you gather evidence for the Fully Developed Claims program in these ways: We’ll request your military service records (with your permission),and and We’ll request relevant Social Security benefits information and medical records that you identify and authorize us to get from a federal facility, like a VA medical center,and and We’ll schedule a health exam for you or get a medical opinion from a health care provider if we decide we need it for your claim Note:Even though we’ll gather federal records (like your DD214 or VA medical records) on your behalf, we encourage you to submit these if you have them to save time in the process. Note:

question: What are the steps involved in the VA disability claim process after it has been filed?
answer: After you file a VA disability claim, the first step is the claim being received, where you will be notified that your claim has been received. The next step is the initial review where your claim will be reviewed. Following this, there is evidence gathering, review, and decision-making process, where evidence is gathered, reviewed, and a decision is made. If more evidence is needed, the claim may return to this step multiple times. Finally, there is the preparation for notification step where the claim decision packet is prepared and then the claim is complete, with a packet being sent to you by U.S. mail with the decision details.

question: What are the key pieces of evidence needed to support a disability claim?
answer: The key pieces of evidence needed to support a disability claim include evidence of a current physical or mental disability from a medical professional, evidence of an event, injury, or disease that occurred during active-duty service, and a link between the current disability and the event, injury, or disease that happened during service. Additionally, medical records or medical opinions from healthcare providers are usually required to support this link. In certain situations, evidence may not be required for a link between military service and disability, such as with chronic illnesses appearing within a year after discharge or illnesses caused by exposure to contaminants or hazardous materials during service.
